thread.title: MSU's Shelton reels in Cook air strikes for 2 TDs
thread.title_full: MSU's Shelton reels in Cook air strikes for 2 TDs

author: detroitnews.com
title: MSU's Shelton reels in Cook air strikes for 2 TDs
text:
Sparty about to exit the tunnel before the game. Michigan State wins 52-26 over Indiana at Spartan Stadium in East Lansing, Mich. on Oct. 24, 2015.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State linebacker Shane Jones celebrates defensive stop on a kick return in the second quarter. Michigan State wins 52-26 Indiana at Spartan Stadium in East Lansing, Mich. on Oct. 24, 2015.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State coach Mark Dantonio talks with an official in the second quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen MSU wide receiver R.J. Shelton makes a catch in the first quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen MSU quarterback Connor Cook (18) throws a touchdown pass in the first quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen MSU wide receiver R.J. Shelton makes a touchdown pass over Indiana's Jameel Cook, Jr. (20) in the first quarter. Shelton (16) pushes for yardage between Indiana's Tegray Scales (8) and Tyler Green (3) in the first quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Rain pours in the first quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State running back Delton Williams (22) scores a touchdown in the second quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen MSU teammates Benny McGowan (75) celebrate with running back Delton Williams (22) after Williams' touchdown in the second quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State quarterback Connor Cook makes a long pass attempt in the third quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Indiana wide receiver Simmie Cobbs, Jr. (1) pulls in a catch with coverage by Michigan State defensive back Demetrious Cox (7) in the third quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State quarterback Connor Cook (18) looks for the open man in the third quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State coach Mark Dantonio talks with officials after a play was reviewed and the ruling on the field upheld in the fourth quarter. The ruling was that an Indiana player had stopped forward motion and therefore did not fumble the ball, which MSU recovered. Michigan State vs Indiana at Spartan Stadium in East Lansing, Mich. on Oct. 24, 2015. Michigan State wins, 52-26. (Robin Buckson / Detroit News)  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State running back LJ Scott runs into the end zone for a touchdown in the fourth quarter with Indiana's Jonathan Crawford (9). With the extra point, it made the score 26-45 Michigan State.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State running back LJ Scott runs 26 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State's Paul Lang celebrates with running back LJ Scott (3) after Scott's touchdown in the fourth quarter to make it 52-26 with the extra point.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State's Joel Heath (92) tries to stop Indiana quarterback Nate Sudfeld in the fourth quarter. Michigan State vs Indiana at Spartan Stadium in East Lansing, Mich. on Oct. 24, 2015. Michigan State wins, 52-26. (Robin Buckson / Detroit News)  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State running back Gerald Holmes (24) runs the ball in for a touchdown in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State quarterback Connor Cook (18) celebrates with running back Gerald Holmes after Holmes' touchdown in the fourth quarter with the extra point making the score 52-26 MSU.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State bench cheers on their teammates in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State wide receiver Macgarrett Kings, Jr. (85) turns upfield after making a catch in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State wide receiver Macgarrett Kings, Jr. (85) turns upfield after making a catch in the fourth quarter, running between Indiana's Dameon Willis (43) and Chase Dutra (30).  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State running back LJ Scott (3) gains yardage in the fourth quarter with Indiana's TJ Simmons (2) trying to trip him up.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State wide receiver R.J. Shelton holds onto a catch in the end zone in the fourth quarter under coverage by Indiana's Jameel Cook, Jr. (20). With the extra point the score is 38-26 MSU.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State defensive end Shilique Calhoun sacks Indiana quarterback Nate Sudfeld (7) for a loss of eight yards in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State defensive end Shilique Calhoun (89) reacts after he sacks Indiana quarterback Nate Sudfeld for a loss of eight yards in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State defensive back Demetrious Cox (7) reacts with Darien Harris after they stop an Indiana offensive drive on fourth down in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Michigan State defensive players Demetrious Cox (7) and Khari Willis celebrate after the stop and Indiana drive on fourth down in the fourth quarter.  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Andrew Kramer, 20, of Pewmo cheers on the team before the game. Michigan State vs Indiana at Spartan Stadium in East Lansing, Mich. on Oct. 24, 2015. (Robin Buckson / Detroit News)  Robin Buckson, Detroit News Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide MSU wide receiver R.J. Shelton makes a touchdown pass over Indiana's Jameel Cook, Jr. (20) in the first quarter. (Photo: Robin Buckson, Detroit News) 
East Lansing — Connor Cook gets the hype, and he should, given he throws one pass after another in the perfect spot.
That doesn't mean they're in the perfect spot for receivers, though.
Michigan State's receivers have to make plays.
"Those are hard catches, hard, contested catches they're making," Cook said following Michigan State's 52-26 victory over Indiana on Saturday at Spartan Stadium. "It's not like I'm hitting a whole lot of wide-open guys."
Aaron Burbridge has been Cook's go-to guy, especially last week against Michigan.
But R.J. Shelton came up big against Indiana, catching a pair of touchdown passes — both, interestingly, on the same play.
In the first quarter, with MSU down 7-0, Cook found Shelton in the right corner of the end zone — Shelton jumping up over two defenders to haul in the 22-yard reception. And in the fourth quarter, with MSU clinging to a 31-26 lead, the Cook-Shelton connection showed up again, back in the right corner of the end zone, this time 13 yards in single coverage.
That was the killer for Indiana, as it came on third-and-9 — and a stop would've kept it a one-possession game.
"I believe the play was the same thing we scored on in the first half," said Dave Warner, co-offensive coordinator. "That play, it's a go-to play for us. We vary it and camouflage it a little bit, but it's a little bit of a go-to play for us when we get down in the red zone.
Burbridge and Josiah Price also caught TD passes for the Spartans (8-0), who saw seven different receivers catch a Cook pass Saturday. Burbridge led the way with eight catches for 128 yards, Shelton had six catches for 76 yards and Macgarrett Kings had seven catches for 69 yards.
"We always talk about who you're go-to guys are, and we're fortunate enough to have a handful of go-to receivers, one who's a tight end," Warner said. "it's sort of a staple of our offense down there."
For Shelton, a junior who had left the stadium before reporters had a chance to catch up with him, those were the sixth and seventh touchdowns of his career — with four of them receptions.
He also has two rushing TDs and one on a kickoff return.
Speaking of kickoff returns, Shelton came up big for a beleaguered special-teams unit.
On the opening kick of the second half, Shelton took it about a step into the end zone, came bursting out and found a hole on his right — scampering for 58 yards. That was a huge boost for an MSU team that only led by a point at halftime.
Less than four minutes later, MSU was in the end zone again.
That was the third-longest kickoff return of Shelton's career, and his longest since the regular-season finale against Penn State last year, when he went 90 yards for a touchdown.
"We played better on special teams," MSU coach Mark Dantonio said. "Our wide receivers had big catches."R.J. Shelton had a big night."
